did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: John P. Clum papers, 1860-1970 (bulk, 1874-1932)
did.abstract: Collection consists of the papers of John P. Clum and family. Correspondence, diaries, scrapbooks, photographs, typescripts, newspaper and magazine articles are by or about John P. Clum; a smaller quantity of typescripts, reprints, and biographical items concern John's son Woodworth Clum. Much of the material consists of writings by the Clums and others about the Apache Indians, Geronimo's capture, and events in Tombstone, Arizona.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: John P. Clum papers (AZ 003). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John P. Clum was an Indian agent at the San Carlos Indian Reservation in southeast Arizona from 1874 to 1877. He later served as founder and editor of the Tombstone Epitaph newspaper, postmaster, and mayor of Tombstone, Arizona, as well as postal inspector and lecturer in Alaska. His son, Woodworth Clum, was an editor of the Washington Star newspaper, and the author of a book about his father entitled Apache Agent.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into 10 series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of the papers of John P. Clum and family. Correspondence, diaries, scrapbooks, photographs, typescripts, newspaper and magazine articles are by or about John P. Clum; a smaller quantity of typescripts, reprints, and biographical items concern John's son Woodworth Clum. Much of the material consists of writings by the Clums and others about the Apache Indians, Geronimo's capture, and events in Tombstone, Arizona. The bulk of the correspondence is between John and his wife Mary Clum, from 1876 to 1880. These letters, a diary from 1875, and some official documents contain information on his tenure as an Indian agent in Arizona.

Photographs, some original but mostly reprints, depict John, Mary, Woodworth, other Clum family members, and friends including Wyatt Earp. Identified Apache individuals are represented in formal portraits taken in Washington, D.C., where Clum took them in 1876. Group photos of Apaches show them on the San Carlos Reservation and other locations, both before and after Geronimo's capture. An 1898 diary, 1898 Alaskan newspapers, scrapbooks, and photographs chronicle Clum's time in Alaska. Miscellaneous items include an 1860 history book, and an account of Clum family history.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional materials concerning John Clum are located in the John P. Clum Collection (MS 284).

Series II: Dairies
John Clum diary. Written in Arizona and on a trip to Washington, D.C. March 1, 1875-December 23, 1875
John Clum diary. Written in Alaska. March 5, 1898-September 7, 1898
Series III: Manuscripts
Autobiography by John Clum, chapters 15-22. Some portions used by Woodworth Clum in his biography of John Clum, entitled Apache Agent. No Date
"Lo, the Poor Indian Agent" by John Clum. No Date
"On the Trail" by John Clum. October, 1875
Fragments of autobiographical manuscripts by John Clum. 1898-1909
Series IV: Publications
The Third Book of History by Peter Parley (Boston: Swan, Brewer and Tileston, 1860). Signed: John P. Clum, Santa Fe, N.M. 1860
Sunset Magazine. Includes an article by John Clum entitled "Fighting Geronimo: A Story of the Apache Indian Campaign of 1876." May, 1906
"Geronimo" by John Clum. Extract from the New Mexico Historical Review. January, 1928
"Victorio, Head Chief of the Warm Springs Apaches in 1877, at Ojo Caliente, New Mexico" by John Clum. Reprint from the New Mexico Historical Review. 1929
"The San Carlos Apache Police, Parts I and II" by John Clum. Reprints from the New Mexico Historical Review. 1929-1930
"It All Happened in Tombstone" by John Clum. One extracted version and one page proof version from the Arizona Historical Review. October, 1929

The Truth about the Apaches Told in the Annual Reports by John P. Clum, United States Indian Agent for the Apache Indians at San Carlos, Arizona. Submitted to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs for 1874, 1875, 1876, 1877 by John Clum (Los Angeles: Adcraft, 1931). One full version and one partial version. 1931
"Nellie Cashman" by John Clum. Extract from the Arizona Historical Review. January, 1931
"John P. Clum" by Leslie E. Gregory. Extract from the Arizona Historical Review. July, 1932
Series V: Clippings

Handwritten transcripts of clippings from the Arizona Citizen. Most concern John Clum and Apaches.
1875-1877

Clippings, primarily from the Tombstone Epitaph. Most concern John Clum and family. Includes clippings on Mary Clum's death (1880) and an assassination attempt on John Clum (1881). Note: Oversize materials from this file are located in Box #6. 1880-1881
Clippings from various newspapers and publications. Most concern John Clum and family. 1880-1975
Clippings concerning the death of John Clum. Includes a typescript of remarks made by Raymond C. Brooks at Clum's funeral. 1932
Series VI: Scrapbooks
Scrapbook. Most of the materials concern John Clum. 1868-1930
Scrapbook. Most of the materials concern John Clum. 1890-1913
Series VII: Legal Documents
Lease of Gilded Age Mining Claim, Tombstone, by John Clum from the Gilded Age Mining Co. June 24, 1880
Quit-claim deed for property in Tombstone from James Clark, John Rouse, and John Anderson to John Clum. April 22, 1882
Series VIII: Miscellaneous Materials
Booklet entitled: Claverack (John Clum was born in Claverack, New York). 1892

Photocopies of three letters from Harold D. Clum to Cornelius W. Clum regarding Clum family history. Includes a Clum coat-of-arms. (Relation of these individuals to John Clum is unknown.). August-September, 1928
Synopsis of the motion picture "Walk the Proud Land," based on John Clum's career as Apache Indian Agent. May 22, 1956

Program from Tau Beta Pi Arizona Alpha Initiation Banquet.
December 4, 1958
Excerpt of letter from Marjorie Clum Parker, John Clum's granddaughter, to Phyllis Ball, University of Arizona Special Collections Librarian. May 17, 1960
